sit.translation[0].definitions[0].defini: to be on a chair or seat, or on the ground, with the top half of your body upright and your weight resting on your buttocks
sit.translation[0].definitions[0].exampl: We used to sit and listen to her for hours.
Jean sat at the table writing a letter.
I sat on the shore and looked at the sea.
She was sitting in a chair by the fire.
She’s the girl who sits next to me at school.
In the driving seat sat a man of average height.
sit.translation[0].definitions[1].defini: to get into a sitting position somewhere after you have been standing up
sit.translation[0].definitions[1].exampl: He came over and sat beside her.
Sam sat opposite her and accepted a cigarette.
sit.translation[0].definitions[2].defini: to make someone sit, or help them to sit
sit.translation[0].definitions[2].exampl: I gently led her to the chair and sat her on it.
sit.translation[0].definitions[3].defini: to be in a particular position or condition
sit.translation[0].definitions[3].exampl: My climbing boots were sitting unused in a cupboard.
The house has sat empty for two years.
a little church sitting on a hillside
The parliament building sits in a large square.
He’s got a computer sitting on his desk, but he doesn’t use it.
sit.translation[0].definitions[4].defini: to stay in one place for a long time, especially sitting down, doing nothing useful or helpful
sit.translation[0].definitions[4].exampl: I spent half the morning sitting in a traffic jam.
Well, I can’t sit here chatting all day.
Are you just going to sit there complaining?
sit.translation[0].definitions[5].defini: to be a member of a committee, parliament, or other official group
sit.translation[0].definitions[5].exampl: They both sat on the management committee.
He was the first journalist to sit in parliament.
sit.translation[0].definitions[6].defini: to have a meeting in order to carry out official business
sit.translation[0].definitions[6].exampl: The council only sits once a month.
The court will sit until all the evidence has been heard.
sit.translation[0].definitions[7].defini: to be in, or get into, a resting position, with the tail end of the body resting on a surface
sit.translation[0].definitions[7].exampl: The cat likes to sit on the wall outside the kitchen.
sit.translation[0].definitions[8].defini: used to tell a dog to sit with the tail end of its body resting on the ground or floor
sit.translation[0].definitions[9].defini: if a bird sits on its eggs, it covers them with its body to make the eggs hatch
sit.translation[0].definitions[10].defin: to look after a baby or child while its parents are out
sit.translation[0].definitions[11].examp: Tracy’s sitting her GCSEs this year.
They were preparing children to sit for the entry examination.
sit.translation[0].definitions[12].defin: to sit somewhere so that you can be painted or photographed
sit.translation[0].definitions[12].examp: She sat for  (=was painted by) Holman Hunt and Millais.
sit.translation[0].note_box[0].sections[: Young children find it almost impossible to sit still.
Mac sat quietly in the back of the car.
She was sitting comfortably on the sofa.
Sit up straight at the table, Maddie.
Suddenly she sat bolt upright and said, ‘What was that?’
She sat cross-legged on the grass.
sit.translation[0].note_box[1].sections[: sit
to be resting your weight on your bottom somewhere, or to move into this position
He was sitting in front of the fire.
She sat on the bed and kicked off her shoes.
Who is the man sitting next to Karen?
sit down
to sit on a chair, bed, floor etc after you have been standing
I sat down on the sofa.
Come in and sit down.
be seated
to be sitting in a particular chair or place
John was seated on my left.
There was a man seated behind the desk.
take a seat
to sit – used especially when asking someone to sit down
Please take a seat – she will be with you in a minute.
Would the audience please take their seats – the show will begin in five minutes.
sink into something
to sit in a comfortable chair and let yourself fall back into it
We switched on the TV and sank into our armchairs.
lounge
to sit in a very comfortable relaxed way
They lounged around all day by the pool.
perch
to sit on the edge of something
He perched on the arm of the sofa.
My sister was perched  (=was sitting) on a high stool.
be slumped
to be sitting while leaning against something, especially because you are injured, drunk, or asleep
They found him slumped against the steering wheel.
squat
to sit with your knees bent under you, your bottom just off the ground, balancing on your feet
A little boy was squatting at the edge of the pool.
